Regional Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 40226 
March 2008 
 
 
   
Capacity Building and Institutional Strengthening of 
the Free Trade Agreement Units of Selected ASEAN 
Member Countries  
(Financed by the People’s Republic of China Regional 
Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund)

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
FTA  –  free trade agreement  
OREI  –  Office of Regional Economic Integration 
RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
SEOM  –  Senior Economic Officials Meeting 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Industry and trade 
Subsector  –  Trade 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, regional cooperation, capacity 
development 
Subthemes  –  Promoting economic efficiency and enabling markets; trade and 
investments; client relations, network, and partnership development 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Head        J.W. Lee, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
 
Director       S. Madhur, OREI  
 
 
Team leader      J.W. Kang, Economist (Trade), OREI 
Team member    C. Nguyen, Regional Cooperation Specialist, OREI

I.   INTRODUCTION   
1.  As a key instrument in the fight against poverty, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has 
identified trade as one of the four pillars of its regional cooperation and integration strategy 
adopted in 2006. The regional cooperation and integration strategy strongly promotes “open 
regionalism”  in  trade.  While  acknowledging  that  the  best  approach  is  a  World  Trade 
Organization-led  process  of  trade  liberalization,  ADB  recognizes  that  there  are  a  growing 
number of free trade agreements (FTAs) in the Asia and Pacific region. The proliferation of 
bilateral and regional FTAs poses new challenges to developing member countries. 
  
2.  As part of ADB’s mandate to support regional integration and cooperation, a meeting 
between the secretary-general of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and 
senior ADB officials was held in January 2006 in Davao, Philippines. The meeting identified 
possible areas for ADB support to the ASEAN economic integration process. ADB fielded a 
consultation mission to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on 24 March 2006 to the ASEAN Senior 
Economic Officials Meeting (SEOM). 
 
3.  Several  activities  were  proposed  and  unanimously  endorsed  by  SEOM  leaders:  
(i) capacity building and training of senior and mid-level trade officials of ASEAN governments;1 
(ii) strengthening the Bureau for Economic Integration and Finance at the ASEAN secretariat;2 
and (iii) strengthening the FTA units3 in ASEAN member countries. During a second ADB–
SEOM meeting on 31 March 2007, newer ASEAN member countries jointly proposed to ADB a 
regional  trade  capacity  support  program,  within  the  framework  of  the  Initiative  for  ASEAN 
Integration, tailored to their specific needs and conditions. 
 
4.  The regional technical assistance (RETA)4 will finance the strengthening of the FTA units 
in the newer ASEAN member countries of Cambodia, Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao 
PDR), and Viet Nam. The RETA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.   ISSUES 
 
5.  ASEAN has been engaged in FTA talks with Australia, People’s Republic of China, India, 
Japan, Republic of Korea, and New Zealand, among others. The growing number of FTAs, 
however, poses unprecedented challenges to ASEAN member countries because of their varied 
and often limited negotiating capabilities and institutional capacities. There is, therefore, a need 
to enhance the ASEAN countries’ abilities to engage in FTA negotiations and to improve their 
knowledge  of  the  ensuing  economic  restructuring  process,  including  effective  trade-related 
adjustment policies. 
 
6.  This need is most apparent in newer members of ASEAN, Cambodia, Lao PDR, and 
Viet Nam. These countries require additional knowledge and expertise in FTA-related issues so 
that they can respond effectively to the increasing number of FTAs with which they are involved, 
so as to maximize benefits and minimize negative effects.  
                                                 
1  Three sessions of FTA training courses were conducted under ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Capacity 
Building for Designing, Negotiating, and Implementing Free Trade Agreements in Selected Asian Developing 
Member Countries. Manila (RETA 6345). 
2  Currently being implemented under ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Capacity of the ASEAN 
Secretariat in Regional Economic Integration and Policy Dialogue. Manila (RETA 6393). 
3   Created in trade ministries (except those established under finance, economy, or foreign affairs ministries), FTA 
units are monitoring the implementation of ASEAN FTAs and are also involved in the negotiation process of other 
FTAs. 
4  This RETA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 4 September 2007.

2   
7.  ADB has responded previously to the proliferation of FTAs by (i) providing assistance to 
developing member countries to build their institutional capacities to negotiate, structure, and 
implement appropriate trade arrangements; (ii) acting as a catalyst and coordinator for regional 
cooperation and integration; and (iii) creating and disseminating knowledge and information to 
support national and regional efforts, including regional policy initiatives such as the Greater 
Mekong Subregion and Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation programs.  
 
8.  This RETA will focus on strengthening the FTA units in Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet 
Nam.  It  will  take  advantage  of  the  expertise  and  experience  of  ADB’s  Office  of  Regional 
Economic Integration (OREI), which has organized and conducted FTA training courses,5 set up 
an FTA and trade and investment database,6 and prepared a forthcoming manual on how to 
design, negotiate, and implement an FTA in Asia.   
 
III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The RETA will enhance the capacity of ASEAN members, in particular Cambodia, Lao 
PDR, and Viet Nam, to respond to trade issues arising from the ASEAN economic integration 
process and to cope with and maximize benefits from FTAs and other trade arrangements. The 
expected outcome is strengthened capacity of the FTA units of Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet 
Nam in negotiating, implementing, and monitoring trade agreements and in forging effective 
trade-related adjustment policies. 
 
B.   Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The RETA  will include three major activities: 
 
(i)  holding in-country specialized training courses for the FTA units of Cambodia, 
Lao PDR, and Viet Nam;   
 
(ii)  carrying out case studies and research on trade-related adjustment measures 
and trade-related issues; and  
 
(iii)  developing  three  country  trade  and  investment  database  structures  to 
complement  the  ASEAN  trade  and  investment  database  (where  key 
macroeconomic, trade, and other regional economic indicators for Cambodia, 
Lao PDR, and Viet Nam can be compiled).  
 
11.  In-Country Specialized Training Courses. A curriculum for a 5-day course on FTAs 
and  specific  topics  such  as  trade  negotiations,  rules  of  origin,  trade  dispute  settlements, 
nontariff barriers, standards, and other trade-related issues will be developed by OREI with the 
assistance of international experts, who will also be used as lecturers and resource persons for 
the  training.  Building  on  ADB’s  existing  FTA training  program,  database,  and manual,  the 
course will cover the economics and scope of FTAs, and strategies for FTA negotiations and 
implementation with special reference to the needs of the three countries. At least three in-
country training courses will be conducted.  
                                                 
5  Three FTA courses were conducted in October 2006, July 2007, and October 2007 at the ADB headquarters in 
Manila. About 100 trade officials from 30 developing member countries across Asia participated in the training 
program.    
6  Available at www.aric.adb.org.

3
 
12.  The training modules, presentations, and reading materials for each training event will 
be compiled in a CD-ROM for future reference by the participants and dissemination to their 
colleagues.   
 
13.  Case Studies and Research. Topics for studies and research will be identified by ADB 
in  consultation  with  the  governments  of  Cambodia,  Lao  PDR,  and  Viet  Nam,  the  ASEAN 
secretariat, and ADB’s Southeast Asia Department. Trade-related adjustment measures will be 
given  high  priority.  This  research  will  be  carried  out  in  collaboration  with  international 
consultants, think tanks in the countries, and concerned government agencies.  
 
14.  Development  of  Country  Trade  and  Investment  Database  Structure.  To  assist 
Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam in consolidating macroeconomic, trade, and investment 
indicators, initial support will be given for developing a database structure and data collection 
mechanism patterned on the database system of the ASEAN secretariat. The country database 
structure  will  be  compatible  with  the  ASEAN  economic  integration  website  currently  being 
developed  under  ADB  technical  assistance  (footnote  2).  Essential  equipment,  including 
computers and software, will be provided to relevant ministries.   
 
C.   Cost and Financing 
15.  The total estimated cost of the RETA is $500,000, funded on a grant basis by the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  Regional  Cooperation  and  Poverty  Reduction  Fund  and 
administered by ADB. The cost will cover remuneration, honoraria, travel, and per diem of 
consultants  and  resource  persons;  training  expenditures;  computers  and  software  for  the 
country  database  system;  and  miscellaneous  expenses.  The  detailed  cost  estimates  and 
proposed financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the Executing Agency. OREI will implement the TA in close cooperation with 
the Southeast Asia Department. There will be collaboration with ADB resident missions and 
host governments in Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam, especially on logistics and protocol, 
during the training courses.  
 
17.  RETA activities will be implemented with the assistance of international and national 
consultants and resource speakers. The international consultants will be trade economists and/ 
or macroeconomists and an IT specialist, who will develop the trade and investment database 
structure in activity 3 (para. 10). A project coordinator and/or economic analyst based in ADB 
headquarters  will  serve  as  overall  coordinator  of  the  FTA  training  courses  and  assist  the 
international consultants in conducting the research studies. Country coordinators and research 
assistants will be hired on an intermittent basis to coordinate activities, including research and 
processing of readily available initial data for the country database systems in their countries of 
assignment. In addition, the RETA will engage national resource speakers for the FTA training 
courses  as  needed.  All  consultants  and  resource  speakers  will  be  engaged  through  the 
individual consultant’s selection method in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The scope of work and outline terms of 
reference for the consultants and resource speakers are in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  Three desktop and one laptop computers will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). Three desktop computers will

4   
be distributed, one per country, at the beginning of the RETA. One laptop computer will be 
allocated to the project secretariat (based in ADB headquarters). Upon RETA completion, the 
equipment will be turned over to the FTA units in the countries or, if used at ADB, will be turned 
over to ADB.  
 
19.  The RETA will finance the training expenses for 30 to 35 participants at each in-country 
FTA training, including travel costs and per diem for those not living near the training venue (as 
determined by the ADB resident missions in the countries).   
 
20.  The governments of Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam will report regularly to ADB. 
They will recommend to ADB through OREI the research topics and other activities to be 
undertaken. Consultations between OREI and the governments will be held every 3 months to 
monitor and evaluate the progress of the RETA.   
 
21.  The RETA is to be implemented over 24 months, from May 2008 to April 2010.  
 
22.  SEOM leaders of Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam consented to their respective 
countries’ participation to the RETA in December 2007. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction 
Fund for Capacity Building and Institutional Strengthening of the Free Trade Agreement Units of 
Selected ASEAN Member Countries and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8       Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE OF TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A  team  of  individual  consultants  will  be  engaged  to  provide  advice  and  technical 
assistance.  A  total  of  39.5  person-months  of  consulting  services  (9.5  person-months  of 
international consulting services and 30 person-months of national consulting services) are 
required. In addition, the regional technical assistance (RETA) will require 1.5 person-months of 
national resource speakers for the free trade agreement (FTA) training course. The person-
month allocations and outline terms of reference follow. 
 
A.  Trade Economist (international, intermittent, 3 person-months) 
2.  The  consultants  will  have  postgraduate-level  background  in  international  trade, 
macroeconomics, or public policy; in-depth expertise in international trade policies, regional 
economic  cooperation,  and  trade  negotiations,  particularly  free  trade  agreements;  and 
substantial knowledge of current developments in economic integration in the Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), with focus on Cambodia, Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
(Lao PDR), and Viet Nam. The consultants will  
 
(i)  assist  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  Office  of  Regional  Economic 
Integration (OREI) and the governments of Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam 
in preparing the FTA training course content tailored to specific needs of the 
countries;  
(ii)  make  presentations  and  facilitate  the  discussions  during  the  in-country  FTA 
trainings, as required; and 
(iii)  undertake other tasks, as required by OREI. 
 
B.   Trade  Economist  and/or  Macroeconomist  (international,  intermittent,  4.5  person- 
months) 
3.  The  consultants  will  have  a  background  in  international  trade,  macroeconomics,  or 
public policy, with in-depth expertise and research experience in selected topics as identified by 
ADB and the governments of Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam.  The consultants will  
 
(i)  prepare an outline and a high-quality paper on the assigned trade topics, such as 
trade  adjustment  measures,  and/or  case  studies  in  close  consultation  with 
governments of Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam;  
(ii)  provide advisory services on relevant trade issues as needed by the countries;  
(iii)  revise the paper based on comments by ADB and concerned agencies of the 
countries;  
(iv)  maintain a list of databases in the region detailing the information and inputs 
being uploaded and analyze the operational effectiveness of those databases; 
(v)  present in workshops or FTA training courses, as required; and 
(vi)  undertake other tasks, as required by OREI. 
 
C.  Information Technology Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
4.  The consultant will have an information and communication technology background and 
experience in database system construction and management. The consultant will  
 
(i)  develop the trade and investment database based on existing operational and  
effective databases in the region;

Appendix 3  9
(ii)  train  the  trade  or  statistics  staff  of  Cambodia,  Lao  PDR,  and  Viet  Nam,  as 
required; and 
(iii)  undertake other tasks, as may be required by the assignment.  
 
D.   Resource Speaker (1.5 person-months, combined) 
 
5.  The resource speakers will be leading scholars or experienced practitioners specializing 
in the topics selected for the in-country FTA training courses. Major responsibilities of each 
resource speaker are the following: 
 
(i)  prepare an outline and/or coverage of topic(s), as well as the reading materials 
for the training;  
(ii)  make a presentation and facilitate the discussion on the topic assigned during 
the training; and 
(iii)  undertake other tasks, as may be required by the assignment.  
 
E.  Project Coordinator and/or Economic Analyst (national, 24 person-months) 
 
6.  The national consultant will have a graduate-level background in macroeconomics or 
international trade and trade expertise in Cambodia, Lao PDR, and/or Viet Nam. Under the 
supervision of the project team leader, the national consultant will  
 
(i)  serve as the overall coordinator of the FTA in-country training in Cambodia, Lao 
PDR, and Viet Nam; 
(ii)  provide research assistance to international consultants; 
(iii)  assist in the implementation of the RETA; and  
(iv)  perform other functions, as may be required. 
 
F.  Country Coordinator and Research Assistant (national, 6 person-months) 
 
7.  The national consultants, based in-country, will have a background in macroeconomics 
or international trade and have work experience in the country of assignment. Under the direct 
supervision of the project team leader and in close coordination with the resident missions, the 
national consultants will  
 
(i)  provide research assistance to international consultants; 
(ii)  serve as country coordinator of the FTA in-country trainings;  
(iii)  assist in the meetings and missions under the RETA; 
(iv)  assist in the processing of initial (readily available) trade and investment data for 
the database; and 
(v)  perform other functions, as may be required.
